message.content: The generated code currently stores users and chats in memory, which means that all data will be lost if the server is restarted. A better approach would be to use a database to persist this data. This could be a SQL database like PostgreSQL or MySQL, or a NoSQL database like MongoDB or Firebase. This would allow the data to persist across server restarts and also make it easier to handle larger amounts of data.

message.content: The test for the login function is failing because the user ID generated during the test does not match the user ID in the application. This is because a new User instance is created both in the test and in the application, and each instance has a unique ID. A possible solution could be to modify the User class to accept an optional ID parameter. This way, you can create a user with a specific ID during testing.

message.content: The test for the login function is still failing. This is because the User instance created in the test is not the same one that is being used in the login function in the application. When the login function is called, it creates a new User instance with a new unique ID, which does not match the ID of the User instance created in the test. A possible solution could be to modify the login function to not create a new User instance, but instead look up the user in the users dictionary using the provided email and password.
